title: 107_s1143
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Ronald Reagan Commemorative Coin Act of 2001" and includes specifications for the coin. The "Ronald Reagan Commemorative Coin Act of 2001" authorizes the minting of $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. Additionally, the Secretary of the Treasury may also mint up to 200,000 $10 bimetallic coins made of gold and platinum. The coins minted under the "Ronald Reagan Commemorative Coin Act of 2001" shall be legal tender as determined by the Secretary, with specifications outlined in the Act. The Secretary will obtain platinum, gold, and silver from available sources for minting coins under this Act. The design of the coins will be determined as outlined in the Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of former President Ronald Reagan's presidency and life, with his likeness on the obverse side and a design similar to an American eagle on the reverse side. Each coin will also feature a value designation, the year "2005", and inscriptions of "Liberty" and "In God". The design for the coins minted under this Act will feature inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated Mint facility from January 1, 2005, to December 31, 2005. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will apply to all sales of coins under this Act. Surcharges for coins issued under this Act will be set by the Secretary, not exceeding $50 for the $10 coin, $35 for the $5 coin, and $10 for the $1 coin. The proceeds from surcharges on coins issued under this Act will be promptly paid to the Department of Health and Human Services for grants to organizations assisting families with Alzheimer's disease care and for increasing awareness. Recipients of these funds will be audited as per the requirements of the law. Financial assurances are also addressed in the Act. SEC. 8 of the Act focuses on financial assurances to ensure no net cost to the government when minting and issuing coins. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantees in place.
